title: Welcome to Big Data for Public Good!
text:
Overview
Public and nonprofit agencies are beginning to unlock the potential of large-scale data to improve service delivery and inform policy. Computational tools capable of making productive use of big data have proliferated in recent years, drastically decreasing the barriers to entry for these applications. This course explores the practice of using data to improve decision-making and evaluation, including techniques for data collection, analysis, and behavior change. You will learn about the opportunities and challenges of big data and devise a plan to apply them to areas of personal interest within the public sector. 


Course Goal & Objectives
By the end of this course you should be able to:

Define big data and describe its characteristics;
Discuss how public agencies harness large-scale data to inform policy design, increase stakeholder engagement, and improve service delivery.
Recognize situations when it’s possible to collect data to inform evidenced-based policy decision-making;
Intelligently consider the social, political, and ethical considerations of using big data and its analytical techniques for public uses.



Helpful Notes from Your Professor

Complete all readings and watch the videos. They compliment each other, so both are critical to understanding course materials
Don’t hesitate to contact me with questions or problems at any point during the semester. I will always try to respond to e-mails quickly.
The topics in this class are in the news all the time. Don’t hesitate to send me or post articles or videos related to course material.



Required Book
No books are required for this course. All learning materials are available through the course site.


Contact Information
Professor A
Phone: (000) 123-4567
Email: Please contact Dr. Cynthia Searcy for question regarding this open course
csearcy@gsu.edu
Office hour:

title: Module 1 - Introduction to Big Data
text: This module introduces you to the opportunities and challenges of big data for the public sector. You’ll learn the characteristics that define big data and begin to think about how to apply it to your own field of study.

title: Module 1 Discussions
text:
Post
Address the following:

Describe two characteristics of big data and how they apply to data produced or used by your field of interest.
Describe ideas presented in two of this week’s readings that you had not considered before.
What questions do you have about big data that we can address this week in class?

Due by: 8/29 11:59 pm EST
Discuss
Online discussions are important to the dialogue and learning in this class. Take some time to respond to at least two of your classmates’ posts by Friday.
Due by: 9/3 11:59 pm EST

title: Module 1 - Introduction to Big Data
text:
1. 2 The Value of Big Data
This module introduces you to the opportunities and challenges of big data for the public sector. You’ll learn the characteristics that define big data and begin to think about how to apply it to your own field of study.

title: Module 1 - Introduction to Big Data
text:
Transforming Information to Ideas
This week we’ll explore the characteristics of big data and its value to the public sector.

title: Module 1 - Introduction to Big Data
text:
Read

Desouza & Smith, Big Data for Social Innovation, Stanford Social Innovation Review, Summer 2014.
World Bank Group, Big Data in Action for Government, World Bank Governance Practice, 2017.
Meier, P., Digital Humanitarians, Chapter 1, CRC Press, 2015.
Pentland, A. Social Physics, Chapter 1, Penguin Group, 2015.

title: Module 1 - Introduction to Big Data
text:
Prepare
Please prepare to discuss your thoughts on the following prompts:

Describe two characteristics of big data and how they apply to data produced or are used by your field of interest.
Describe ideas or practices in this week’s readings that you had not considered before.
What claims about social physics do you find valid? In what ways would you challenge Pentland’s “promise” of social physics?
